title: Runswick Bay to Kettleness Circular Walk Route

images.title: Runswick Bay by Graham Horn, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Runswick Bay. The picturesque fishing village is one of the highlights of the Yorkshire coast with its sandy beach, sheltered bay and pretty little cottages. The white thatched property on the seafront is notable as the only remaining thatched house on the Yorkshire coast.

images.title: Runswick Bay by Graham Horn, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Runswick Bay Beach

images.title: Disused Railway Line heading to Kettleness by Clive Nicholson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Disused Railway Line heading to Kettleness

images.title: Steve  F, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Somewhere to relax at Kettleness

images.title: Kettleness by SMJ, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Kettleness. The small settlement only consists of half-a-dozen houses, but up until the early 19th century, it was a much larger village. However, most of that village, which was on the headland, slipped into the sea as a result of instability caused by quarrying for the alum industry. Kettleness became a smaller hamlet, with houses rebuilt slightly further inland.

images.title: Stephen McCulloch / Site of Kettleness ironstone mine
images.caption: Site of Kettleness ironstone mine. Historically, the hamlet has had an alum works, a jet mining industry and ironstone workings. The hamlet used to have a railway station on the Whitby, Redcar and Middlesbrough Union Railway, that was open between 1883 and 1958.

images.title: Phil Catterall / Disused railway bridge in fine order
images.caption: Disused railway bridge in fine order. The footpath from Westfields Farm down to Runswick Bay travels over this bridge. The stonework is in excellent condition.

description: A circular walk from Runswick Bay to Kettleness on the North Yorkshire coast. The route uses a section of the Cleveland Way to take you along the coast path to Kettleness before returning via the dismantled railway line running between the two settlements. On the way there's some excellent views over the bay with woodland and countryside scenery on the return leg. It's about a 5 mile walk on elevated cliff top paths before a fairly flat railway path section.
